DataElement.preferredName: Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma Inflammatory Infiltrate Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that describes the kind of inflammatory infiltrate cells present.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The most common morphologic subtype of urinary bladder carcinoma (over 90% of cases).  It arises from the transitional epithelium.  It most often affects males in their sixth and seventh decades of life.  Hematuria is the most common symptom at presentation.  Pathologic stage is the strongest predictor of survival.__A microscopic finding indicating the presence of acute, subacute or chronic inflammation in a tissue sample.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The most common morphologic subtype of urinary bladder carcinoma (over 90% of cases).  It arises from the transitional epithelium.  It most often affects males in their sixth and seventh decades of life.  Hematuria is the most common symptom at presentation.  Pathologic stage is the strongest predictor of survival.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that arises from the urothelial lining of the bladder.  It is the most common morphologic type of urinary bladder carcinoma. It usually affects males in their sixth and seventh decades of life.  Hematuria is the most common symptom at presentation. Pathologic stage is the strongest predictor of survival.

Property.preferredDefinition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence of acute, subacute or chronic inflammation in a tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence of acute, subacute or chronic inflammation in a tissue sample.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for TCGA Bladder EPC per request by J.Demchok. mc 1/31/13 Released per approval by John. mc 3/20/13

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence of acute, subacute or chronic inflammation in a tissue sample._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (LIM-fo-site) A type of white blood cell. Lymphocytes have a number of roles in the immune system, including the production of antibodies and other substances that fight infection and diseases.

Concepts.definition: White blood cells formed in the body's lymphoid tissue. The nucleus is round or ovoid with coarse, irregularly clumped chromatin while the cytoplasm is typically pale blue with azurophilic (if any) granules. Most lymphocytes can be classified as either T or B (with subpopulations of each); those with characteristics of neither major class are called null cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of white blood cell that surrounds and kills microorganisms, removes dead cells, and stimulates the action of other immune system cells.

Concepts.definition: A cell that arises from stem cells and/or bone marrow-derived monocytes that function in different aspects of host defense and tissue repair; such as phagocytosis, cytotoxic activity, and regulation of the immune response (antigen presentation and T-cell activation).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

Concepts.definition: Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Granular leukocytes with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by a slender thread of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and stainable by eosin.

Concepts.definition: Granular leukocytes with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by a slender thread of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and stainable by eosin.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence of acute, subacute or chronic inflammation in a tissue sample.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence of acute, subacute or chronic inflammation in a tissue sample.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
